entries.author: Georgia Nicols

entries.title: Man charged in fatal Washington Heights shooting
entries.summary: <p>A man was charged in a fatal shooting that took place Tuesday in Washington Heights, according to Chicago police.</p><p>Bobby Martin, 26, faces a charge of first-degree murder, police said.</p><p>Antoine Alexander, 32, was in a parking lot at 9411 S. Ashland Ave., about 3:30 p.m. Tuesday when Martin, who police said Alexander knew, walked up to him and shot him in his abdomen, according to police and the Cook County medical examiner’s office.</p><p>Alexander, of the Auburn Gresham neighborhood, was taken to Advocate Christ Medical Center in Oak Lawn, where he was pronounced dead, according to the medical examiner’s office.</p><p>Martin is due in court Friday.<br></p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Connor Bedard's fire not enough to carry Blackhawks in loss to Predators
entries.summary: <p>NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Publicly, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks" target="_blank" >Blackhawks</a> star Connor Bedard isn't shy about his competitiveness. Privately, his peers say he's even more competitive than he lets on publicly.</p><p>So while Bedard would never admit it, weeks of watching Team Canada’s Olympic run — which fell just short — while he sat around idly surely lit a fire underneath him.</p><p>That fire was obvious Thursday. In fact, it resembled a blazing inferno. On a night when many of his Hawks teammates looked rusty in a 4-2 loss to the Predators, Bedard singlehandedly generated the majority of his team’s offense.</p><p>He ripped his 24th goal off a savvy pass from <b>Ryan Greene</b> in the second period, broke in alone on Predators goalie <b>Justus Annunen</b> a full three additional times and hunted down loose pucks aggressively.</p><p>Seventeen of the Hawks’ 27 scoring chances occurred with Bedard on the ice. He also took faceoffs for the first time since his Dec. 12 shoulder injury, winning seven of 16.</p><p>“That’s the Connor we’ve seen lots of,” coach <b>Jeff Blashill</b> said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">CONNOR BEDARD WITH A WICKED SHOT 🏒 <a href="https://t.co/5GyHI1cSdy">pic.twitter.com/5GyHI1cSdy</a></p>— NHL (@NHL) <a href="https://twitter.com/NHL/status/2027205208346927410?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 27, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>However, the Hawks let a 2-1 lead in the third period slip away. Predators veteran <b>Ryan O’Reilly </b>outsmarted Hawks rookie <b>Sam Rinzel</b> to tip in the game-winning goal with 3:15 left.</p><p>Bedard, striking his usual public humble tone, praised Greene and <b>Andre Burakovsky</b> for setting him up for “five or six Grade A” chances.</p><p>“That’s on me to put one more of those in and maybe it’s a different game,” he said.</p><p><b>QB search</b></p><p>The Bears have found their franchise quarterback in <b>Caleb Williams</b>, but the Hawks are still searching for their quarterback on the power play.</p><p>They spread out reps between Rinzel, <b>Artyom Levshunov</b>,<b> Kevin Korchinski</b> and veteran <b>Matt Grzelcyk</b> during the past week of practices. Although Rinzel quarterbacked the top unit Thursday, that job is very much available to claim during the stretch run.</p><p>“We’ve got [defensemen] that have shown they’re capable of being power-play guys,” Blashill said. “We’d like to see one or two guys grab it and show they’re elite at it. There’s a difference there.”</p><p>Levshunov <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2026/01/30/blackhawks-artyom-levshunov-reset-break-foundational-skills-jeff-blashill" target="_blank" >returned to the lineup</a> Thursday and quarterbacked the second unit. He committed a costly turnover in the first period, but Blashill said he "got better as the game went along."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">On the Artyom Levshunov turnover-turned-goal, Blashill said Levshunov probably needed to "eat it" but also put blame on Frank Nazar for not supporting him. <br><br>"We took off up the ice like there was no pressure, but there was actually tons of pressure."<a href="https://t.co/A6EETLzwDx">pic.twitter.com/A6EETLzwDx</a></p>— Ben Pope (@BenPopeCST) <a href="https://twitter.com/BenPopeCST/status/2027235854062629288?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 27, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p></p><h3>Entry fees</h3><p>The Hawks also recently practiced a wider variety of power-play zone-entry strategies after their “one drop pass” approach went stale in January. They worked on an entry with two drop passes and another entry with zero, where the initial puck-carrier sneaks into the zone on his own.</p><p>Both new entries were on display during a successful third-period power play. A zero-drop entry by <b>Frank Nazar</b> created one extended zone sequence. A minute later, a two-drop entry back to Bedard created another extended sequence culminating in a <b>Tyler Bertuzzi</b> goal.</p><p>“I like that [two-drop entry] where I can get that much speed and come in,” Bedard said. “I feel pretty confident about it when I have those gaps.”</p><p><b>Extra attacker</b></p><p>The Hawks haven’t practiced six-on-five situations (with the goalie pulled) much this season, but they finally did Monday. They converted a couple times in practice, so it’ll be interesting to see if that makes a difference down the stretch. They’re the only NHL team with zero goals in those situations. They came up empty again Thursday.</p><p><b>Only one</b></p><p>Defenseman <b>Wyatt Kaiser</b> is the Hawks’ lone injured player. He has resumed skating individually as he works his way back from a Feb. 4 knee injury and could return to action next week.<br></p>
entries.author: Ben Pope

entries.title: Bulls pick good night to lose and the right team to lose to in Portland
entries.summary: <p>Coach and front office can’t always be philosophically aligned.</p><p>Thursday was the latest reminder of that.</p><p>In the green corner were executive vice president Arturas Karnisovas and sidekick/general manager Marc Eversley, knowing all too well that Trail Blazers success means Bulls success. The Bulls hold Portland’s lottery-protected first-round pick, but only if the Blazers make the playoffs. Otherwise, it carries over for another year through 2028.</p><p>In the red corner was the coach from Rockville Centre, New York, who continues spending long nights in the office trying to figure out how he can help will this mishmash of a roster to a victory. Billy Donovan doesn’t know any other way.</p><p>Something had to give.</p><p>For the 11th consecutive time, it was Donovan and the roster he has been given.</p><p>As a result of another high-turnover game — 20 in this one — the Bulls (24-36) stumbled to the worst month in franchise history with an 0-11 February, losing 121-112.</p><p>The Bulls got 20 points from Matas Buzelis, but even he wasn’t great on a 6-for-16 shooting night.</p><p>Not that Karnisovas & Co. should have minded much. Portland’s win kept the Blazers in the No. 9 spot for the play-in, still trying to close in on the No. 8 Warriors.</p><p>And while Donovan wasn’t looking to offer a helping hand in that, he also wasn’t oblivious to the entire situation, especially with the prospect of adding a second first-round pick in a loaded class.</p><p>“The discussions I had with them when the trade deadline was finalized was, ‘Nothing has changed, try and get these guys to play to the best of their ability; we know it’s going to be somewhat challenging with seven new players,’ ’’ Donovan said. “Even talking to ownership, it’s been, ‘Hey, go out there and do your very best.’ There has been no indication from ownership or the front office of, ‘Hey, listen, if we finish here, here or here’ or ‘Listen, don’t worry about playing these guys; just play these guys.’ There’s been none of that at all.</p><p>“Philosophically, I get the dynamics once June, whatever date that draft date is, I get how that impacts all of that. It’s not like I’m sitting over there saying, ‘Well, it’s a close game right now, let’s sit Josh [Giddey] and Tre [Jones] and Jalen [Smith].’ There has not been that. And I think if I did do that, they would say, ‘Listen, you need to put the best guys out there.’ ’’</p><p>It’s a nice idea for Donovan to hold on to, but with the pressure the front office is starting to feel, it’s not in its best interests to play the “best guys” at this point. It made sure of that by trading some of the team’s better guys.</p><p>If Donovan needed a reminder of that, it came in the last minutes after a dunk by Leonard Miller cut the deficit to three with 3:37 left. Rather than build off that and continue the rally, the Bulls’ defense fell apart. Donovan’s squad was outscored 13-7 to close the game out.</p><p>It’s the third-longest losing streak in franchise history.</p><p>“We’re not making excuses; we don’t think we’re 11-game-losing-streak bad,” forward Isaac Okoro said. “At this point, we just have to come to the game focused and do the little things right. Blocking out, not turning the ball over, not letting them get second-chance points. Just doing the little things, and we can win games.”</p>
entries.author: Joe Cowley
